Name: Ecuador
Overview: The Ecuadorian Central Bank launched a digital currency, the Sistema de Dinero Electrónico (SDE), in 2014. Due to low levels of trust in the central bank, the project failed and was cancelled in 2017.
Key Developments: The Sistema de Dinero Electrónico (SDE) was launched by the Ecuadorian Central Bank (BCE) towards the end of 2014. Ever since 2000, the US Dollar has been the official currency of Ecuador, and each dollar in SDE was backed by a physical dollar stored in the BCE. The officially listed motives behind the launch included improving access to banking for poorer citizens and reducing dependency on physical cash. Although the BCE predicted 500,000 users by the end of 2015, only 5,000 ended up signing up. At the end of 2017, there were 402,515 accounts, yet less than 30% were ever used. In 2016, the SDE accounted for less than 0.003% of currency in circulation. Widespread mistrust of the BCE, largely due to previous government defaults, contributed to the meager adoption of the SDE, and the project was shut down in December 2017.

Name: Senegal
Overview: The West African Economic and Monetary Union (WAEMU) decided in 2016 to use member-state Senegal as a testing ground for a potential union-wide digital currency. However, early on in development, WAEMU's central bank withdrew support, and the project subsequently failed.
Key Developments: In early 2016, Dublin-based digital currency specialist eCurrency Mint entered talks with the central bank of the West African Economic and Monetary Union (WAEMU), Banque Centrale des Etats de l’Afrique de l’Ouest (BCEAO). Senegal, one of the members countries of WAEMU, was determined to be the site of a soft launch of eCurrency Mint’s technology and serve as a testing ground for a union-wide digital currency. Thus, in November 2016, a regional Senegalese bank, Banque Régionalede Marchés (BRM), announced the launch of a digital currency called the eCFA in Senegal, named after WAUMU’s hard currency CFA. Importantly, the eCFA in Senegal was not declared legal tender by the BCEAO, but rather an experiment that the central bank could observe and learn from. However, the eCFA digital currency was soon rebuked by the BCEAO due to a lack of compliance with e-money regulations. Once the BCEAO started to distance itself from the project, it lost traction and was cancelled. In addition, the central bank expressed that it had no desire to establish a CBDC in the foreseeable future.
Cross-border partnerships: West African Economic and Monetary Union
Central Bank Name: Central Bank of West African States

Name: France
Overview: The Bank of France has played a significant role in testing the potential for a digital euro. Several experiments using a digital euro have been conducted in the past few years in collaboration with the ECB, BIS, and private sector banks.
Overview Spotlight: The Bank of France has played a significant role in testing the potential for a digital euro.
Key Developments: In May 2020, the Bank of France successfully experimented with using CBDC – the digital euro – through blockchain technology. The experiment entailed testing a sale of securities and was run by Société Générale Forge. Nearly a year later, in late April 2021, the Bank of France collaborated with Société Générale Forge and the European Investment Bank (EIB) to use CBDC to settle digital bonds issued by the EIB via blockchain. The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) Innovation Hub, Banque de France and Swiss National Bank launched Project Jura that, together with a private sector consortium led by Accenture, will conduct an experiment using wholesale CBDC (wCBDC) for cross-border settlement on a distributed ledger technology (DLT) platform. On June 18, the Banque de France successfully conducted a wholesale CBDC experiment with SEBA Bank, as part of the experimental program launched in March 2020. Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.
Key Developments Spotlight: In May 2020, the Bank of France successfully experimented with using CBDC – the digital euro – through blockchain technology. The experiment entailed testing a sale of securities and was run by Société Générale Forge. Nearly a year later, in late April 2021, the Bank of France collaborated with Société Générale Forge and the European Investment Bank (EIB) to use CBDC to settle digital bonds issued by the EIB via blockchain.

Name: Brazil
Overview: The Brazilian Central Bank is building on the success and rapid adoption of its instant payment system, Pix, which was launched in November 2020. In addition, the Central Bank is exploring the digitization of its national currency, the real. Guidelines for the upcoming CBDC were released in May 2021, although no timelines for implementation were released.
Key Developments: On May 24, 2021, Brazil’s Central Bank released general guidelines for the digitization of the real, the national currency. This move is part of Brazil’s agenda for modernizing payments, which has already seen the institution of instant payments system PIX and the launch of an open banking initiative. The digital real will be intermediated by the National Financial System and the Brazilian Payments System. Although the central bank stated that there were further discussions necessary before the solidification of implementation timelines, it specified certain goals such as adherence to security and privacy principles, interoperability, and integration with a view to enabling cross-border payments. On June 11, 2021, the central bank clarified that it would take two to three years until a CBDC would be implemented. In addition, the Brazilian Central Bank’s instant payment system Pix, which was launched in November 2020, has been adopted by more than 87.3 million users as of May 2021, and more than 1.549 billion transactions have been processed. Two new features to Pix, Pix Saque and Pix Troco, should be released in August 2020, according to the central bank. These features will enable cash withdrawals and receiving change at commercial establishments and service providers.

Name: Haiti
Overview: The Bank of the Republic of Haiti is planning to start testing a digital version of the Haitian gourde by the end of the year and continue through 2022. Development of the currency in early to mid-2020.
Key Developments: Speaking at a presentation for the Official Monetary and Finacial Institutions Forum (OMFIF), central bank governor Jean Báden Dubois hailed the "revolutionary" potential of a CBDC for Haiti's economy. He emphasized that implementation of the digital gourde would both boost financial inclusion (in a country where only 46% of the population is banked) and improve the interoperability of the country's payments systems.
Central Bank Name: Bank of the Republic of Haiti

Name: Israel
Overview: Although the Bank of Israel has yet to commit to the issuance of a CBDC, it announced in May 2021 that it would accelerate its research on the topic. The Bank also publicly released a draft model for what the digital shekel would look like in order to promote professional discussion.
Key Developments: The Bank of Israel has been considering the issue of a digital shekel since 2017. In November 2018, a team from the Bank of Israel released a report that recommended holding off on issuing a digital currency in the near future. In May 2021, the Bank published a report titled, “A Bank of Israel Digital Shekel – Potential Benefits, Draft Model, and Issues to Examine.” In the report, they announced they would accelerate their research and development efforts on a digital currency. Although, they clearly specified they have not committed to the issuance of a CBDC, they are laying the groundwork for eventual CBDC preparedness. Next steps involve the creation of a CBDC steering committee to explore the topic further.

Name: South Africa
Overview: In February 2021, South Africa’s Intergovernmental Fintech Working Group (IFWG) announced the launch of Project Khokha 2, exploring use of the blockchain at the wholesale level in South Africa. In May 2021, the South African Reserve Bank (SARB) announced a feasibility study on use of digital currencies at the retail level, expected to conclude in 2022.
Key Developments: As part of Project Khokha 2, the IFWG will simulate a real-world trial to explore the use of distributed ledger technology in the financial sector and work on technologies such as tokenized money at the wholesale level. SARB’s separate study of retail digital currency use is designed to investigate the use of an electronic legal tender complement to cash, though the Bank has not yet decided to issue a retail CBDC. In March 2019, SARB invited bids from private companies to develop CBDC infrastructure. However, South Africa's future capacity for financial innovation has been threatened recently by several digital currency start-ups seeking to relocate out of the country, citing unclear regulatory policies and the Mirror Trading scandal that defrauded over 23,000 investors last year.

Name: Switzerland
Overview: In December 2020, the Swiss National Bank (SNB) announced the successful completion of a wholesale digital currency trial, called Project Helvetia, though added that no decision had been made on whether to issue its own digital money to facilitate transactions between financial institutions. The Bank has not yet announced research on implementation of a retail digital currency.
Key Developments: Project Helvetia explored the feasibility of issuing a wholesale CBDC onto financial infrastructure operator SIX’s distributed digital asset platform and linking that platform to the existing wholesale payment system. In April 2021, the SNB announced an upcoming cross-border digital currency trial with an unnamed foreign central bank, using a currency other than the Swiss franc. These research developments come despite a report by the country’s Federal Council in December 2019 on the benefits and risks of a central bank digital currency that concluded that a “universally accessible central bank digital currency would bring no additional benefits for Switzerland at present.”

Name: Japan
Overview: On April 5th 2021, the Bank of Japan announced that it is entering a proof of concept phase to test the technical feasibility of the core functions and features required for a CBDC.
Key Developments: The Bank of Japan confirmed that it has started central bank digital currency trials. In Proof of Concept Phase 1, the Bank plans to develop a test environment for the CBDC system and conduct experiments on the basic functions that are core to CBDC as a payment instrument such as issuance, distribution, and redemption which will last for a year until March 2022. The Bank of Japan has not yet decided whether to proceed with a CBDC and plans to have more clarity by late 2022. In March, Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda also spoke about some of the drivers. Japan’s objectives are a little different from most countries because of the heavy use of cash in retail payments and the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, which caused widespread disruption. Hence there is a greater emphasis on the ability to execute payments offline.

Name: Jamaica
Overview: The Bank of Jamaica is currently engaged in a seven month pilot of a CBDC using its Fintech Regulatory Sandbox. They currently plan to nationally roll out the digital currency in early 2022.
Key Developments: In a July 2020 press release, the Bank of Jamaica (BoJ) invited CBDC providers to submit development and testing plans for CBDC solutions in a controlled environment in its recently established Fintech Regulatory Sandbox. In March 2021, the BoJ announced that it had chosen eCurrency Mint as its partner and would pilot the digital currency in its sandbox from May to December. It plans to initiate a national rollout of the currency in early 2022. Financial inclusion, improved management processes and costs, and commitment to Jamaica's transition to a digital economy were cited as the potential benefits of using CBDCs. The digital currency is also expected to promote economic recovery in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Name: Lebanon
Overview: Lebanon's central bank has been developing a CBDC and announced in November 2020 that they would seek a 2021 debut of the digital currency. So far, no updates have been provided. This project is a move to restore confidence in Lebanon’s banking sector in an effort to fight the country’s economic and financial crises.
Key Developments: Lebanon’s central bank has been considering the idea of a state-run digital currency since at least 2018. Efforts accelerated in 2020 after violent protests and silent bank runs deepened the crisis of Lebanon’s financial system. Faced with a dollar crisis, banks tightened restrictions on foreign currency transactions, with at least one major institution limiting withdrawals to just $400 a month. A plunging Lebanese lira made it almost impossible to transact in the local currency. In June 2020, protestors set fire to the central bank in Tripoli, angry over the collapse of the lira, which would eventually plunge to more than 5,000 lire per dollar before rebounding. The growing confusion over the Lebanese fiat currency triggered a wave of Bitcoin buying among locals, with peer-to-peer marketplaces like Localbitcoins seeing a sharp rise in activity. A main motivator of Lebanon's CBDC project is to create a cashless system that promotes the flow of money, as Lebanese citizens currently store over $10 billion in their homes and the economy relying heavily on remittances from its citizens living abroad.

Name: Mauritius
Overview: The Central Bank of Mauritius first began exploring a CBDC in November of 2019. The governor of the central bank of Mauritius confirmed in May 2020 that his country would progress in the development of a CBDC. In May 2021, the governor announced plans to launch a pilot program by the end of the year.
Key Developments: In order to facilitate creation of a CBDC, the Mauritian introduced a series of regulatory changes in their Finance Act 2020, including a new definition of a “digital currency,” clarification that the currency can only be issued by the central bank, and guidance that the central bank can determine its denomination, design, form and manner. The Finance Act also provides that currency issued by the central bank, including digital currency, shall be legal tender in Mauritius. Mauritius has already demonstrated familiarity with cryptocurrency, creating a licensing regime for custodians and issuing guidance on security tokens last year.

Name: Russia
Overview: The Bank of Russia first released a report analyzing a possible ruble-backed CBDC in October 2020. In March 2021, the deputy chairman of the Bank of Russia said that the release of the first prototype of a Russian CBDC will come out in late 2021.
Key Developments: In October 2020 the Central Bank of Russia announced plans to release a prototype CBDC in 2021. 83% of the feedback the bank had received was in favor of its development. The Bank plans to draft regulatory norms for the currency’s integration in 2022. The proposed digital ruble would be built on a hybrid platform with distributed ledger technology, likely using open-source code. Some Russian banks and fintech companies have expressed concerns that the models proposed are excessively centralized and could harm private banks' business by forcing them to compete with the central bank, while analysts are concerned about the degree of economic control a digital ruble could grant the central bank, possibly including the ability to bar unfavored entities from the Russian economic system. The Central Bank of Russia has also stated that launching a CBDC will decrease their dependence on the US dollar and potentially help in side-stepping US sanctions.

Name: Turkey
Overview: In December 2020, the Central Bank of Turkey announced a pilot form of the digital lira with the conceptual phase already completed and to be rolled out in the latter half of 2021. Details remain murky about the Bank’s progress, and prior to the announcement they were not tracked to be developing a digital currency, although a local outlet reported in September 2020 that the Bank was hiring experts for its digital currency research and development team.
Key Developments: The Turkish Ministry of Treasury and Finance announced in March 2021 that it was beginning work with regulatory bodies in the country to assess the risks posed by digital currencies and to devise government solutions, with currency academic and lecturer İsmail Hakkı Polat also speculating that the moves could pave the way for digital currency taxes in Turkey as soon as late 2021.
Central Bank Name: Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey

Name: Nigeria
Overview: The Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN), which has been researching the e-Naira for more than two years, announced in July that it would begin a CBDC pilot in October 2021.
Key Developments: On June 10, 2021, Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) IT Specialist Rakiya Mohammed shared that the bank had been exploring the option of a digital naira for more than two years. Regarding a potential launch, Mohammed said the following: “Before the end of the year, the Central Bank will be making a special announcement and possibly launching a pilot scheme in order to be able to provide this kind of currency to the populace.” In July, CBN announced that it would launch a CBDC pilot as early as October 2021. One of the primary motives behind issuing a digital naira is to improve foreign remittances, which is the second largest forex revenue in the country after oil. Other motivations include financial inclusion and the opportunity to regulate the rise of private cryptocurrencies.

Name: Bahrain
Overview: A collaboration between the Central Bank of Bahrain, Bank ABC, and JP Morgan is currently developing a cross-border digital currency settlement pilot program. This collaboration is expected to focus on developing a CBDC in the near future.
Key Developments: In early 2020, the Central Bank of Bahrain announced that it would pilot the CBDC Policy-Maker Toolkit developed by the World Economic Forum as part of the CBB's research on the impact of digital currencies on the economy. In May 2021, the CBB began collaborating with JP Morgan and Bahrain-based Bank ABC to pilot an instantaneous cross-border payment system using US dollars. The collaboration between the three parties is expected to eventually extend to a CBDC.

Name: Canada
Overview: Although researching the topic for years, the Bank of Canada currently has no immediate plans to launch a digital currency. However, it maintains an initiative to build the capability to launch a national digital currency should the need arise and has explored cross-border digital payments. This is part of a broader strategy for the Bank of Canada to fulfill its mandate and address any possible developments with regards to the future of payments and money.
Key Developments: Canada’s digital currency initiative is one among a portfolio of contingencies to adapt to and prepare for the future of money and payments. According to the Bank of Canada, it would consider launching a digital currency if “the use of bank notes were to decline to a point where Canadians no longer had the option of using them for a wide range of transactions;" or a competing digital currency were to become a widespread alternative to the Canadian dollar. In early December 2020, Timothy Lane, the Bank of Canada deputy governor in charge of financial technology, stated that COVID-19 may expedite Canada’s need for a CBDC. The pandemic has accelerated the move towards a digital economy, and less widespread cash usage indicates that a fundamental shift may occur sooner than anticipated. However, the Bank of Canada still does not have a concrete timeline for launch. As recently as late May 2021, Lane said that any digital currency the Bank of Canada may offer would be more environmentally friendly than Bitcoin. He shared that the central bank has been studying environmental impacts as part of research on a potential CBDC.

Name: Uruguay
Overview: The Central Bank of Uruguay successfully completed a digital currency pilot program in April 2018 to issue, circulate, and test payments in an e-Peso. The pilot ended in 2018 and has been at a standstill since then.
Key Developments: Uruguay’s e-Peso pilot was part of a broader government initiative to promote financial inclusion. The pilot ran for 6 months beginning November 2017, issuing 20 million e-Pesos to 10,000 users. Individuals and businesses could hold 30,000 and 200,000 e-Pesos, respectively, in digital wallets. Transfer took place via mobile phones using text messages or an e-Peso app. 6 institutions were involved in the pilot, both from the public and private sectors. The pilot was considered a success and closed in April 2018 to evaluate results and inform additional design decisions. In particular, officials were evaluating how to manage the stock of digital banknotes in different denominations as well as how to manage the level of anonymity.

Name: Curaçao
Name of CBDC: Digital Curaçao and Sint Maarten Guilder
Overview: Since 2018, the Central Bank of Curaçao and Sint Maarten (CBCS) has been exploring the creation of a CBDC in partnership with Bitt Inc., a Barbados-based fintech company.
Key Developments: In August 2018, the CBCS and the Bitt signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to jointly explore the feasibility of issuing CBDC (Digital Curaçao and Sint Maarten Guilder) for the two nations. In the MOU, Interim Director of the CBDCS Leila Matroos-Lasten noted that the central bank seeks to "address its challenges proactively by exploring the latest technology available, for example, to reduce the level of cash usage within the monetary union, and to facilitate more secure, more [anti-money laundering] and [Know Your Customer] compliant, and more efficient financial transactions in and between Curaçao and Sint Maarten.”
Central Bank Name: Central Bank of Curaçao and Sint Maarten

Name: Sint Maarten
Name of CBDC: Digital Curaçao and Sint Maarten Guilder
Overview: Since 2018, the Central Bank of Curaçao and Sint Maarten (CBCS) has been exploring the creation of a CBDC in partnership with Bitt Inc., a Barbados-based fintech company.
Key Developments: In August 2018, the CBCS and the Bitt signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to jointly explore the feasibility of issuing CBDC (Digital Curaçao and Sint Maarten Guilder) for the two nations. In the MOU, Interim Director of the CBDCS Leila Matroos-Lasten noted that the central bank seeks to "address its challenges proactively by exploring the latest technology available, for example, to reduce the level of cash usage within the monetary union, and to facilitate more secure, more [anti-money laundering] and [Know Your Customer] compliant, and more efficient financial transactions in and between Curaçao and Sint Maarten.”
Central Bank Name: Central Bank of Curaçao and Sint Maarten

Name: Finland
Overview: The Suomen Pankki (SP), Finland’s central bank, acknowledged the potential of CBDC in a report released in 2017. No further updates have been issued since the report.
Key Developments: The SP recognized the growing interest in CBDCs and suggested that it would conduct research into potential benefits. The SP hasn’t ruled out distributed ledger technology (DLT) but viewed blockchains as slow, poorly scalable, and with latency issues. Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.

Name: Denmark
Overview: The Central Bank of Denmark conducted research on digital currencies in 2016 and 2017, determining that it would pose significant legal, financial, and administrative challenges and no clear benefits for the Danish society. It currently has no plans to issue a CBDC.
Key Developments: The Central Bank of Denmark explored the viability for a national digital currency (E-krone) in 2016 and 2017. The critical question, Central Bank Governor Lars Rohde noted, was whether the CBDC "should be anonymous or not." In its December 2017 report, the Danish Central Bank concluded that "the potential benefits of introducing central bank digital currency for households and businesses in Denmark would not match the considerable challenges which this introduction would present." Citing Denmark's existing secure and effective payment infrastructure, the report noted that the efficiency gains from a CBDC does not outweigh the risks of financial instability that a CBDC can lead to the risk of systemic bank runs.

Name: Egypt
Overview: The Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) announced that it was exploring the value of a CBDC in December 2018. No further updates have been made since the announcement.
Key Developments: In 2018, CBE vice-governor Ayman Hussein announced a study on the viability of digital currency integration in cooperation with several unnamed international financial institutions. At that time, an estimated 84% of the country was unbanked, complicating the effective launch of a digital currency system.

Name: Malaysia
Overview: In March 2021, the Central Bank of Malaysia, announced that it does not have any immediate plans to issue a CBDC. The Bank's annual report stated that the financial system in Malaysia continues to support the functioning of the economy while meeting the needs of individuals and businesses.
Key Developments: Undecided

Name: North Korea
Overview: North Korean authorities have shown significant interest in bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies; however there is no evidence that the government is pursuing a CBDC.
Key Developments: Undecided
Central Bank Name: Central Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea

Name: Trinidad and Tobago
Overview: While the Central Bank of Trinidad and Tobago welcomes financial technology developments and believes that they can improve financial stability, as of November 2018, the bank does not view the development of a digital currency as a priority.
Key Developments: The Central Bank of Trinidad and Tobago is committed to engaging with financial technology companies to develop a better understanding of potential applications for itself and domestic institutions. However, a statement the bank released in November 2018, indicated that it does not view the development of a digital currency as priority but will continue to study the area.
Central Bank Name: Central Bank of Trinidad and Tobago

Name: Venezuela
Overview: In October 2018, the Venezuelan government launched the Petro, a digital currency backed by oil, gold, iron, and diamond resources. Though accompanied by innovative CBDC legislation and a strong blockchain ecosystem, the Petro was not widely adopted and is not being actively used today.
Key Developments: In February 2021, President Nicolas Maduro hinted at development of a new currency called the digital bolivar, promising an forthcoming "surprise" in the Venezuelan financial space. This announcement on a surprise digital bolivar project led to significant speculation among experts on Venezuela's currency space. Some believe that an entirely new digital currency is soon to be released, while others believe the project to simply be an attempt to dollarize the economy. None are sure about the impact a digital bolivar will have on the Venezuelan government's commitment to the failed Petro.

Name: Antigua and Barbuda
Overview: The digital currency DCash was officially launched and available to members of the public on March 31, 2021.
Key Developments: After developing a digital currency since 2019, the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB) launched its digital currency DCash in March 2021 in 4 of its 8 member states. With DCash, the Eastern Caribbean has become the first currency union central bank to issue digital cash. The digital currency pilot is available for use by the public on their smartphones. Consumers and merchants can utilize the DCash App or use it through participating financial institutions.

Name: Saint Kitts and Nevis
Overview: The digital currency DCash was officially launched and available to members of the public on March 31, 2021.
Key Developments: After developing a digital currency since 2019, the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB) launched its digital currency DCash in March 2021 in 4 of its 8 member states. With DCash, the Eastern Caribbean has become the first currency union central bank to issue digital cash. The digital currency pilot is available for use by the public on their smartphones. Consumers and merchants can utilize the DCash App or use it through participating financial institutions.

Name: Saint Lucia
Overview: The digital currency DCash was officially launched and available to members of the public on March 31, 2021.
Key Developments: After developing a digital currency since 2019, the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB) launched its digital currency DCash in March 2021 in 4 of its 8 member states. With DCash, the Eastern Caribbean has become the first currency union central bank to issue digital cash. The digital currency pilot is available for use by the public on their smartphones. Consumers and merchants can utilize the DCash App or use it through participating financial institutions.

Name: The Bahamas
Overview: In December 2019, the Central Bank of the Bahamas launched the Sand Dollar project on the island of Exuma. After the successful pilot in Exuma, the digital currency fully launched across the country in October 2020. The sand dollar is the first ever nationwide Central Bank Digital Currency in the world. Now, the Central Bank is working on achieving full interoperability between its various wallet providers
Overview Spotlight: In December 2019, the Central Bank of the Bahamas launched the Sand Dollar project on the island of Exuma.
Key Developments: In October 2020, the Sand Dollar became the first CBDC in the world to go beyond the pilot stage and achieve an official launch. The digital currency became available for use by all Bahamian citizens upon release, while integration with the commercial banking system has been subject to a gradual rollout. The completion of that integration is now imminent, according to the bank. The motivations for the CBDC pilot include improving financial inclusion and strengthening security against money laundering or illicit economic activities. In its statement announcing Project Sand Dollar, the Central Bank of the Bahamas noted that it will "simultaneously promote the development of new regulations for the digital currency, and strengthen consumer protection, especially around data protection standards" as the pilot in Exuma progresses. The Central Bank is now working on achieving full interoperability between its various wallet providers.
Key Developments Spotlight: In October 2020, the Sand Dollar became the first CBDC in the world to go beyond the pilot stage and achieve an official launch. The digital currency became available for use by all Bahamian citizens upon release, while integration with the commercial banking system has been subject to a gradual rollout. The completion of that integration is now imminent, according to the bank.

Name: Grenada
Overview: The digital currency DCash was officially launched and available to members of the public on March 31, 2021.
Key Developments: After developing a digital currency since 2019, the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB) launched its digital currency DCash in March 2021 in 4 of its 8 member states. With DCash, the Eastern Caribbean has become the first currency union central bank to issue digital cash. The digital currency pilot is available for use by the public on their smartphones. Consumers and merchants can utilize the DCash App or use it through participating financial institutions.

Name: Argentina
Notes: No development yet but starting to think about it

Name: Croatia
Notes: Unlikely to have a digital kuna, more likely to see digital euro

Name: Macau
Notes: China CBDC allows "cross-border payments" to Macau

Name: South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands
Marshall Islands
Overview: The Marshall Islands first released their plans for a digital currency named the Marshallese Sovereign (SOV) in February 2018. However, the implementation of a Marshallese CBDC would reduce the country's dependence on US tender, while incorporating more of its unbanked population into the local economy and further integrating the island nation into the global economy. SOV is not a CBDC as the Marshall Islands does not have a central bank.
Key Developments: In contrast to projects like the Bahamian Sand Dollar or China's digital yuan, the Marshallese SOV will not be a representation of the local fiat currency (USD), but will be an independent coin, in circulation alongside the US dollar. Algorand has said that the SOV supply will be regulated by the government of the Marshall Islands and will be algorithmically fixed to grow at 4% per year. In March 2021, IMF representative Sarah Zhou sounded a voice of caution on the SOV rollout and said that the issuance of the Marshall Islands’ digital sovereign currency as legal tender would “raise risks to macroeconomic and financial stability as well as financial integrity” of the islands, “resulting in a significant drag on the economy.” If issued, the SOV’s launch will be preceded by an 18-to-24-month Timed Release Monetary Issuance, or presale, to gauge liquidity and market interest.

Name: Federated States of Micronesia
Overview: Micronesia and Palau have begun to develop a for the issuance of CBDCs. However, they are yet to announce official plans for their CBDC.
Key Developments: Micronesia and Palau have partnered with blockchain companies Sovereign Union and Apollo Fintech to create a National Payment Platform for the issuance of CBDCs. The companies’ proposed ledger applications include the National Payment Platform for the issuance of Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDC) and the Apollo E-Government Platform. Both island nations have embraced the accessibility of a digital currency in an effort to transition their largely unbanked populations towards a cashless economy.
Notes: No new developments; overview from April 20 CBDC tracker update

Name: Palau
Overview: Micronesia and Palau have begun to develop a for the issuance of CBDCs. However, they are yet to announce official plans for their CBDC.
Key Developments: Micronesia and Palau have partnered with blockchain companies Sovereign Union and Apollo Fintech to create a National Payment Platform for the issuance of CBDCs. The companies’ proposed ledger applications include the National Payment Platform for the issuance of Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDC) and the Apollo E-Government Platform. Both island nations have embraced the accessibility of a digital currency in an effort to transition their largely unbanked populations towards a cashless economy.
Notes: No new developments; overview from April 20 CBDC tracker update

Name: Cambodia
Overview: In October 2020, the National Bank of Cambodia launched Bakong, which is a DLT-based interbank payment system, with the goal of promoting financial inclusion and supporting rural financial sector development. Several months later, the project is already seeing widespread adoption and acceptance.
Key Developments: Following several years of research and exploration, in October 2020, the National Bank of Cambodia (NBC) launched Project Bakong, a DLT-based interbank payments system. Bakong was developed in partnership with Japanese fintech firm Soramitsu, Some of the stated goals of Bakong include promoting financial inclusion, supporting rural financial development, easing access to credit for small businesses, and decreasing dependence on the US Dollar. As of April 2021, the platform has nearly a third of the Cambodian population onboard. Although there is some confusion throughout the media and international community, Bakong is not a CBDC according to the NBC.

Name: Dominica
Overview: Although the ECCB digital currency which has launched in four of the eight states so far is not yet available in Dominica. Authorities say that after the twelve-month run, the ECCB will assess the feasibility of a full commercial launch to all eight of their member countries.
Key Developments: After developing a digital currency since 2019, the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB) launched its digital currency DCash in March 2021 in 4 of its 8 member states. With DCash, the Eastern Caribbean has become the first currency union central bank to issue digital cash. The digital currency pilot is available for use by the public on their smartphones. Consumers and merchants can utilize the DCash App or use it through participating financial institutions.

Name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines
Overview: Although the ECCB digital currency which has launched in four of the eight states so far is not yet available in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. Authorities say that after the twelve-month run, the ECCB will assess the feasibility of a full commercial launch to all eight of their member countries.
Key Developments: After developing a digital currency since 2019, the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB) launched its digital currency DCash in March 2021 in 4 of its 8 member states. With DCash, the Eastern Caribbean has become the first currency union central bank to issue digital cash. The digital currency pilot is available for use by the public on their smartphones. Consumers and merchants can utilize the DCash App or use it through participating financial institutions.

Name: China
Overview: In April 2020, China became the world's first major economy to pilot a digital currency. The People's Bank of China is aiming for widespread domestic use of the e-CNY by 2022 and is trying to make it possible for foreign athletes and visitors to use its digital yuan during the Beijing Winter Olympics in 2022.
Key Developments:
In 2017, as a part of a wider push to develop its high-technology sectors, China launched a project called Digital Currency Electronic Payments, or “DCEP." Since then, Chinese officials have said the digital currency will have “controllable anonymity," allowing the government to provide a level of privacy while also regulating against money laundering and other illicit activity. In April 2020, China piloted the digital currency in four cities, allowing commercial banks to run internal tests like conversions between cash and digital money, account-balance checks, and payments. In August, the piloted program expanded to 28 major cities. As of June 2021, the PBOC announced that more than 20.87 million personal 3.51 million corporate digital yuan wallets had been opened, with a total transaction value of around $5.39 billion.

The PBOC has also begun laying the groundwork for digital currency to be used in cross-border transactions. Aiming for broad circulation in 2022, the People’s Bank of China and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority have begun ‘technical testing’ for cross-border use of the digital yuan as of April 2021 and plan to test it with foreign visitors at the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics. This is in addition to a separate announcement made in February 2021 that the PBOC joined central banks from Thailand, the United Arab Emirates, and Hong Kong to explore a cross-border wholesale CBDC project named Multiple Central Bank Digital Currency (m-CBDC) Bridge.

The PBOC has also experimented with additional features in its programmable money including expiration dates. In July 2021, the PBOC announced that foreign travelers to China will be able to use e-CNY even without domestic bank accounts if they provide their passport information.
Notes: Overview of China is from April update of CBDC tracker

Name: Ukraine
Overview: The National Bank of Ukraine successfully completed a two-month pilot of a national digital currency, the e-hryvnia in February 2019. In January 2021, the bank signed a deal with Stellar Development Foundation in order to develop a CBDC, among other tasks related to virtual assets. Their work begins in August 2021.
Key Developments: The National Bank of Ukraine has been exploring the possibility of issuing a national digital currency since 2016. In 2018, interest ramped up significantly when it announced it was considering launching a digital currency based on blockchain which culminated in a successful two-month pilot of the e-hryvnia, between December 2018 and February 2019. In June 2020, the Ministry of Digital Transformation passed a bill called “On Virtual Assets” that regulates the circulation and distribution of virtual assets, as well as officially legalizes the activity. In January 2021, the central bank signed a deal with Stellar Development Foundation. The company will promote the development of a CBDC in Ukraine, and officially starts its activities in August 2021. Legislation to legalize cryptocurrency is also currently awaiting passage as lawmakers work towards a favorable taxation environment for cryptocurrency.
Notes: Overview & Key Developments from April 2021 update (doesn't seem to be much happening until August, when rollout happens)

Name: Sweden
Overview: Sweden has been at the forefront of CBDC development, and is currently in the testing stages of its e-krona currency.
Key Developments: In a continuation of the Riksbank's testing of digital currency, the e-krona will advance from only simulated participants to a testing environment with external participants. The Riksbank announced in April 2021 that it would involve commercial banks in the next phase of the CBDC project in order to evaluate the e-krona's use for large commercial and small retail payments.

Name: Anguilla
Overview: Although the ECCB digital currency which has launched in four of the eight states so far is not yet available in Anguilla. Authorities say that after the twelve-month run, the ECCB will assess the feasibility of a full commercial launch to all eight of their member countries.
Key Developments: After developing a digital currency since 2019, the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB) launched its digital currency DCash in March 2021 in 4 of its 8 member states. With DCash, the Eastern Caribbean has become the first currency union central bank to issue digital cash. The digital currency pilot is available for use by the public on their smartphones. Consumers and merchants can utilize the DCash App or use it through participating financial institutions.
Notes: Anguilla is part of the ECCB which has launched a pilot CBDC, but this pilot is only active in Antigua and Barbuda, and there are no plans as of yet to extend to Anguilla

Name: Montserrat
Overview: Although the ECCB digital currency which has launched in four of the eight states so far is not yet available in Montserrat. Authorities say that after the twelve-month run, the ECCB will assess the feasibility of a full commercial launch to all eight of their member countries.
Key Developments: After developing a digital currency since 2019, the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB) launched its digital currency DCash in March 2021 in 4 of its 8 member states. With DCash, the Eastern Caribbean has become the first currency union central bank to issue digital cash. The digital currency pilot is available for use by the public on their smartphones. Consumers and merchants can utilize the DCash App or use it through participating financial institutions.

Name: Thailand
Overview: Thailand's Central Bank has been moving forward with its three to five year target for launching a CBDC. After a successful cross-border wholesale pilot with Hong Kong, the central bank is planning to launch a retail CBDC pilot in the second quarter of 2022.
Key Developments: In January of 2020, the Bank of Thailand and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority published a study on the application of central bank digital currencies for cross-border payments. They developed a cross-border corridor network allowing participating banks to conduct peer-to-peer foreign exchange transactions. This was titled Project Inthanon-LionRock and was deemed a success. BoT and HKMA signed a contract with ConsenSys to conduct cross border transactions in September of 2020, and are working on a proof of concept. In February 2021, it was announced that the United Arab Emirates and China will join the project and it would be renamed “Multiple Central Bank Digital Currency (m-CBDC) Bridge.” Although Thailand has piloted a wholesale CBDC through Project Inthanon-LionRock, it is still prepping for its retail CBDC pilot planned for 2022. In June 2021, Thailand's Central Bank announced it had hired German payments technology provider Giesecke + Devrient to design its CBDC prototype, allocating 10 million baht for the project.

Name: Hong Kong
Overview: As of April 2021, the People’s Bank of China and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority have begun testing for cross-border use of the digital yuan.
Key Developments: In January of 2020, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Bank of Thailand published a study on the application of central bank digital currencies for cross-border payments. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and Bank of Thailand developed a cross-border corridor network allowing participating banks to conduct peer-to-peer foreign exchange transactions. This was titled Project Inthanon-LionRock and was deemed a success. HKMA and BoT signed a contract with ConsenSys to conduct cross border transactions in September of 2020, and are now working on a proof of concept. In February 2021, it was announced that the United Arab Emirates and China will join the project and it would be renamed “Multiple Central Bank Digital Currency (m-CBDC) Bridge.” The HKMA is also working with the People’s Bank of China to test the use of the digital yuan for cross-border payments. The HKMA confirmed that the first phase of tests, which involved select merchants and a bank, has been succesful.

Name: Saudi Arabia
Overview: Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates launched a bilateral CBDC pilot project called Project Aber in 2019, and concluded that DLT can successfully facilitate cross-border transactions.
Key Developments: Saudi Arabia first launched Project Aber with the UAE in late 2019. The goal with the project was to look at the feasibility of developing a cross-border digital currency. Project Aber was different from most pilot programs as two central banks and a further three commercial banks from each country were involved in the project. The high-level objectives of Aber were: to research DLT technology and to explore its suitability for such an experiment; to see whether inefficiencies of the existing cross-border payments could be overcome using a CBDC; as well as gaining knowledge and experience in DLT technology and the challenges of deploying a mutualized infrastructure. The project's conclusion in November 2020 confirmed that a cross-border dual issued currency was technically viable and that it was possible to design a distributed payment system that offers significant improvements over a centralized payment system.

Name: United Arab Emirates
Overview: The United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia launched a bilateral CBDC pilot project called Project Aber in 2019, and concluded that DLT can successfully facilitate cross-border transactions.
Key Developments: The United Arab Emirates first launched Project Aber with Saudi Arabia in late 2019. The goal with the project was to look at the feasibility of developing a cross-border digital currency. Project Aber was different from most pilot programs as two central banks and a further three commercial banks from each country were involved in the project. The high-level objectives of Aber were: to research DLT and to explore its suitability for such an experiment; to see whether inefficiencies of the existing cross-border payments could be overcome using a CBDC; as well as gaining knowledge and experience in DLT and the challenges of deploying a mutualized infrastructure. The project's conclusion in November 2020 confirmed that a cross-border dual issued currency was technically viable and that it was possible to design a distributed payment system that offers significant improvements over a centralized payment system. In February 2021, it was announced that the United Arab Emirates will join China, Hong Kong, and Thailand in a joint CBDC cross-border test. This “Multiple Central Bank Digital Currency (m-CBDC) Bridge” will test the use of DLT for foreign currency payments, with the hope of eventually expanding to other Asian nations.
Cross-border partnerships: Saudi Arabia, China, Thailand, Hong Kong
Central Bank Name: Central Bank of the United Arab Emirates

Name: Singapore
Overview: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has been a leader in testing CBDCs through its Project Ubin. In 2019, Singapore and Canada conducted the first successful international transaction of CBDCs.
Key Developments: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is discussing the creation of multiple CBDC arrangements to improve speed, cost, and transparency of cross-border payments. As part of Project Ubin, the MAS has developed a prototype multi-currency wholesale settlement network, to enabled the issuance and distribution of different CBDCs on a common network.

Name: South Korea
Overview: The Bank of Korea launched a 22-month pilot program in April 2020 to research the legal and technical implications of CBDC. While they originally claimed they have no plans to launch a CBDC in the near future, the central bank has accelerated their research to keep pace with other countries’ progress.
Key Developments: The Bank of Korea announced in May 2021 that it will choose a technology supplier to build the pilot platform for its digital currency through an open bidding process. The pilot program is planned to run from August to December 2021. This announcement came after the BoK was successful in overcoming some offline communication issues by using what they call secure elements. On July 20, 2021, the BoK announced that it would partner with Ground X, a subsidiary of Korea-based internet company Kakao, for its upcoming pilot.

Name: Lithuania
Overview: According to the Bank of Lithuania, the country's digital currency LBCOIN is the world‘s first blockchain-based digital collector coin. Together with its physical version, LBCOIN was issued on 23 July 2020.
Key Developments: As of May 2021, the Bank of Lithuania has released 24,000 collector tokens created using the blockchain technology. When purchasing LBCOIN, buyers get 6 randomly selected digital tokens and upon collecting a token from each of the 6 categories, consumers can redeem a physical silver coin. Tokens are available for purchase and storage on the Bank of Lithuania's e-shop.

Name: United Kingdom
Overview: The United Kingdom has launched a joint taskforce between the Treasury and the Bank of England to investigate a potential CBDC.
Key Developments: In April 2021, the Bank of England announced an upcoming partnership with HM Treasury to launch a CBDC Taskforce to explore the viability of UK CBDC. Also announced in this statement were the creations of a CBDC Engagement Forum and CBDC Technology Forum with the purpose of gathering input and fostering dialogue. In late September, the Bank announced that Forum membership would include stakeholders from Google, PayPal, Mastercard, Visa, Amazon Web Services, HSBC, Morgan Stanley, and SWIFT, among others. There is still no guarantee that the Bank of England will pursue a CBDC, but it has been clarified that “the Bank now intends to deepen its exploration of CBDC.”

Name: Kuwait
Overview: The Central Bank of Kuwait is developing a CBDC infrastructure. However, the CBK noted that "plans for a national cryptocurrency are currently pending."
Key Developments: In its 2019 Banking Report, the Central Bank of Kuwait included a CBDC system as part of its Kuwait National Payment System initiative so that the Digital Dinar "can be launched quickly by CBK should it choose to do so."

Name: Italy
Overview: In late 2020, the Italian Banking Association (ABI) announced ongoing research contributions to the European Central Bank's (ECB) work on the digital euro, though the Bank of Italy has not mentioned any specific involvement.
Overview Spotlight: In late 2020, the Italian Banking Association (ABI) announced ongoing research contributions to the European Central Bank's (ECB) work on the digital euro.
Key Developments: In June 2020, the ABI announced interest in being involved with digital euro development. In a previous initiative called Project Spunta, more 100 of the association's banks joined to develop blockchain technologies to improve automated reconcialiation interbank accounts. Much of the same team will be involved in the digital euro research, focusing on technical feasibility and use cases enabled by distributed ledger technology. Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.
Key Developments Spotlight: In June 2020, the ABI announced interest in being involved with digital euro development.

Name: Estonia
Overview: In October 2020, Eesti Pank, the Bank of Estonia announced it would launch a multi-year research project on the viability of a CBDC in the country.
Key Developments: In 2018, a government spokesperson for Estonia stated that the country had no plans to launch a digital currency. However, in 2020 the central bank announced a multi-year research project in partnership with Guardtime and the SW7 Group on the viability of a digital currency. The research is focused on how the country could benefit from a CBDC and what kind of technology would be suitable for the Estonian economic context. Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.
Notes: Wrote overview and Key dev (not on current tracker)

Name: Netherlands
Overview: The Central Bank of Netherlands (DNB) plans to proceed in a leading role in the euro zone with research and development. Its plan will likely involve cooperation and communication with the European Central Bank, under whose mandate the discussion of CBDC falls.
Key Developments: The Central Bank of the Netherlands (DNB) published a report in April 2020 that weighed the implementation of a possible CBDC. The report outline some of the motivations for a CBDC launch, including declining cash use and the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic. The DNB clarified that the mandate for CBDC issuance falls with the ECB, but stated “If the decision should be taken within the eurosystem to experiment with some more concrete type of CBDC, we are ready to play a leading role. The Netherlands provides a suitable testing ground for such an experiment.” The bank also provided some insight into possible CBDC models. In particular, they argued against the use of DLT for digital currencies, citing risks such as high costs and inefficient use of electricity. Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.

Name: Spain
Overview: The Spanish central bank is participating in efforts to study the impact of a digital euro on the nation’s financial systems and economy. As of the end of June 2021, the current ruling Spanish Socialist Party proposed the creation of a national digital currency separate from the European Union.
Key Developments: In October 2020, the Spanish central bank, Banco de España, released a strategic plan in outlining its primary goals from 2020 to 2024. In this plan, the bank states that it will investigate the impacts of a digital euro on the Spanish economy and financial system as well as develop digital euro design proposals. In late June 2021, the Spanish Socialist Party (PSOE), the current governing political body, proposed the creation of a national digital currency, separate from the European Union. PSOE presented the proposition to the Spanish Congress to create a national digital currency, ostensibly as a response to decreased usage of physical cash and to promote “the recovery of money as a public good, more stable and under democratic control.” In another statement, PSOE stated that this new digital currency “would end the ‘privilege’ of banks over money,” noting that the project would be achieved “without the nationalization of the banking system or the nationalization of credit.” Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.

Name: Germany
Overview: The German Bundesbank is taking a conservative approach toward adopting a digital euro. It is currently evaluating a digital currency's potential benefits and downsides as well as risks and opportunities.
Key Developments: At the start of 2020, the German crypto law came into effect. It regulates licensing of crypto assets for private entities and is expected to incentivize banks to create services related to crypto assets. In October 2020, Burkhard Balz, a German politician and executive board member of the country's central bank, said that Germany is looking into alternative digital payment solutions that would prevent the undesirable implications of using CBDCs. To that end, the Bundesbank tested a blockchain-based distributed ledger for electronic securities that would negate the need for CBDCs in March 2021. Thus, the bank is looking into using blockchain technology and smart contracts in tandem with conventional forms of payment. Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.

Name: Euro Area
Overview: After multiple exploratory reports on the feasibility of a digital euro were commissioned in 2020 and 2021, the ECB launched the investigation phase of its CBDC project in July 2021.
Key Developments: The ECB's working paper suggests a two-tier system for a “general purpose” CBDC. The paper states that the use of CBDC for efficient retail payments will be the most likely driver behind initiatives. It rejects the motivation of using CBDC as a store of value, which would involve consumers switching deposits from commercial banks into CBDC. The CBDC would be interest-bearing, with attractive interest rates offered for smaller sums suitable for payments and lower rates would be available for larger amounts. In June 2021, the ECB released a report titled “The international role of the euro,” which concluded that “issuing a CBDC would help to maintain the autonomy of domestic payment systems and the international use of a currency in a digital world.” This conclusion is in line with President Christina Lagarde’s statements that a digital currency could be launched within four years in the EU. In July 2021, the ECB announced that would launch a 24 month investigation phase for the digital euro project, which aims to address key issues regarding the design and distribution of a digital euro. The investigation phase will include focus groups, prototyping and conceptual work. Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.

Name: Georgia
Overview: In May 2021, the National Bank of Georgia announced that it is considering the launch of a CBDC.
Key Developments: In its May 2021 press release, the National Bank of Georgia (NBG), announced it would begin exploring the prospect of a digital Gel. The NGB announced it would develop a CBDC through a public-private-partnership, and is currently in the process of working with fintech firms to join the effort. In the same announcement, the NGB listed several features of its future CBDC, including a modular approach, low cost, convenience for retail, and interoperability.

Name: Iran
Overview: The Central Bank of Iran and the Iranian government have been jointly working on developing a national digital currency to circumvent economic sanctions imposed by the United States and facilitate cross-border transactions. In December 2019, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani even called for a Muslim cryptocurrency to cut dependence on the dollar.
Key Developments: After the United States’ withdrawal from the Iran Nuclear Deal and reimplementation of sanctions in 2018, Iran began to actively pursue the development of a national digital currency. In July of 2018, Alireza Daliri, the head of investment affairs for Iran’s Science and Technology Department, said over the next three months they would integrate blockchain technology with the central bank for implementation of a cryptocurrency across domestic banks. While it does not appear that Iran has issued a rial-backed digital currency, reports indicate that a gold-backed cryptocurrency has been launched in collaboration with Kuknos Company and four Iranian banks. Titled PayMon, it is intended to tokenize bank assets and properties. Notably, Iran has also sought cooperation with Russia and Armenia by signing a trilateral blockchain agreement.
Central Bank Name: The Central Bank of the Islamic Republic of Iran

Name: Kazakhstan
Overview: In May 2021, the National Bank of the Republic of Kazakhstan announced that it has plans to pilot a CBDC known as the “digital tenge.” It is currently in the process of planning the pilot through a series of research studies and discussions with stakeholders.
Key Developments: In May 2020, Mu Xin, a senior Kazakh government adviser, proposed the introduction of blockchain technology and the digital tenge. This would aim to combat corruption and ensure transparency in the allocation of state budget funds. In June, Kazakhstan adopted a development outline for blockchain and digital technology. Kazakh officials revealed the nation’s digital currency development plan to experts from Russia and China in June 2020. In May 2021, the Kazakhstan central bank announced that it plans to pilot a new legal currency called the “digital tenge.” The bank also laid out a roadmap for the future of the digital currency: in May 2021 they published a report on the digital tenge, this will then be widely discussed before the pilot project begins. Once the pilot concludes, a report will be compiled before a decision is made on whether to launch a full-scale digital tenge project.

Name: Ghana
Overview: The Bank of Ghana is exploring a CBDC and has launched a fintech regulatory and innovation live testing pilot that will give preference to projects using blockchain technology.
Key Developments: The Bank of Ghana Governor Ernest Addison announced in a keynote address in 2019 that Ghana is researching a CBDC and the possibilities for a pilot project in a sandbox environment. In February 2021, the central bank of Ghana launched a fintech regulatory and innovation live testing pilot that will give preference to projects using blockchain technology. According to a press statement published by the bank, the sandbox will cover a broad spectrum of innovations in the financial services sector, targeting women and improving financial inclusion in the country. The bank is on the lookout for remittance products, crowdfunding products and services, e-KYC (electronic know your customer) platforms and new merchant payment solutions for small to medium-sized businesses.
Notes: No new developments since April, edited some typos in the Key Developments section

Name: Madagascar
Overview: Banky Foiben'i Madagasikara, the Central Bank of Madagascar, is carrying out a two-phase project to study the issuance of e-Ariary. The first phase will focus on analysis, design, and experimentation. If experimentation is successful, the project will enter the implementation phase.
Key Developments: In response to growing international interest in CBDCs, the Central Bank of Madagascar published an one-pager outlining its approach to CBDC research, project e-Ariary, in October 2020.

Name: Iceland
Overview: While Iceland is a popular destination for cryptocurrency mining activities, the legality of cryptocurrencies in Iceland is less clear. The Central Bank of Iceland is exploring the possibility of issuing a retail CBDC, Rafkróna.
Key Developments: When a pseudonymous founder released Auroracoin as the "unofficial national digital currency of Iceland" in 2014, the Central Bank of Iceland warned that it was not a recognized currency. The Central Bank of Iceland released an interim research report for issuance of a CBDC, Rafkróna, in 2018, noting that it "does not recommend that the rafkróna be introduced, and no decisions have been taken on the matter. Discussions with stakeholders lie ahead, as do further analysis and assessments of the pros and cons of issuing a rafkróna." In June 2019, the Financial Supervisory Authority of Iceland (FME) approved Monerium's e-money license to issue fiat-backed stablecoins using the ethereum blockchain.

Name: Australia
Overview: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is actively exploring the use of a wholesale eAUD. The RBA conducted a proof of concept to simulate a wholesale settlement system involving commercial banks in the country. The RBA is committed to continue this research throughout 2020 to ascertain the viability of a digital Australian dollar, and has partnered with Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank, Perpetual and ConsenSys Software.
Key Developments: RBA announced in November 2020 that they have partnered with Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank, Perpetual and ConsenSys Software to “explore the potential use and implications of a wholesale form of central bank digital currency (CBDC) using distributed ledger technology (DLT)." This partnership will involve the creation of a proof-of-concept “for the issuance of a tokenized form of CBDC that can be used by wholesale market participants for the funding, settlement and repayment of a tokenized syndicated loan on an Ethereum-based DLT platform." The project should have ended at the end of 2020 and a report on the findings is expected to be published by mid-2021.

Name: Eswatini
Overview: The Central Bank of Eswatini is conducting a four-phase study to examine the use cases of CBDC in Eswatini in 2019 in partnership with the Center for Financial Regulation and Inclusion (Cenfri).
Key Developments: In February 2020, the Central Bank of Eswatini published its phase 1 report. The study explored three use cases: payments, consumer, and economic policy. The Bank is currently in the process of collating feedback from key stakeholders and experts on the feasibility of use in Eswatini.
Notes: Overview from April, added info on current state of research

Name: India
Overview: In early 2021, the Indian government introduced a bill to create a facilitative framework for creation of the official digital currency to be issued by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). The bill also suggests a ban on all private cryptocurrencies in India.
Key Developments: The legislation, listed for debate in the current parliamentary session, seeks "to prohibit all private cryptocurrencies in India, however, it allows for certain exceptions to promote the underlying technology of cryptocurrency and its uses.” In mid-2019, a government panel recommended banning all private cryptocurrencies, with a jail term of up to 10 years and heavy fines for anyone dealing in digital currencies. The panel did, however, ask the government to consider the launch of an official government-backed digital currency in India, to function like bank notes through the RBI. In February 2021, the RBI released a report describing the pros and cons of a digital currency. Although they acknowledged the potential financial inclusion benefits, they also claimed introduction of a CBDC could lead to disintermediation in the banking sector. In March 2021, RBI Governor Shri Shaktikanta Das noted, “As the underlying technology is still developing, we are exploring ways for a clear, safe and legally certain settlement finality, which is most crucial for a secure and efficient payment system.” In July 2021, the RBI announced that it considering a series of pilot studies for an eventual “phased” rollout of a CBDC.

Name: Indonesia
Overview: In May 2021, Governor Perry Warjiyo of the Bank Indonesia (BI) announced that Indonesia would be launching a digital rupiah currency. It is currently in the process of determining which platform to utilize and how the CBDC can be leveraged to meet its policy priorities.
Key Developments: Bank Indonesia, like many other central banks, has been influenced by the rise of cryptocurrencies and will continue to monitor the space. However, the bank has outlawed the use of cryptocurrencies for payments, fearing their destabilizing effects and use in illicit activity. Regarding this issue, former finance minister Chatib Basri stated the central bank needed a digital currency to counter the circulation of cryptocurrencies. In May 2021, the BI Governor confirmed that they would pursue the launch of a digital rupiah in light of the increasing trend toward digital payment mechanisms. The digital currency will be regulated in the same way cash-based transactions are, and BI is currently working on creating the necessary regulatory infrastructure. The official timeline for release has yet to be publicly announced.

Name: Kenya
Overview: The Central Bank of Kenya has started exploring the possibility of introducing a CBDC in Kenya, said CBK Governor Patrick Njoroge in October 2020.
Key Developments: At Georgetown's DC Fintech Week in October 2020, CBK Governor Njoroge noted that the CBK has been in discussion with global players about CBDC and that the push to study CBDCs "comes as a result of mushrooming of private cryptocurrencies."
Notes: No new developments, typos in April Key Dev section

Name: Morocco
Overview: In February of 2021, the Moroccan Central Bank announced the formation of an exploratory committee to investigate the pros and cons of a digital currency after banning cryptocurrencies four years ago. This committee seeks to determine the advantages and drawbacks a CBDC could have for the Moroccan economy.
Key Developments: Although Morocco has announced the formation of its exploratory committee, the central bank has stated that it will continue to take a cautious approach in analyzing the advantages for the Moroccan economy that a digital currency would bring, given the speculative nature of existing cryptocurrencies. Although Morocco's central bank is not considering releasing a prototype of a digital currency anytime soon, it will coordinate with other authorities within the country about measures to take with respect to other crypto-assets. Moreover, even though Moroccan citizens are still banned from owning or trading Bitcoin, the digital currency industry in the country continues to thrive. In fact, Morocco is regarded as one of the top digital currency markets in Africa.
Notes: No new developments since April, added some notes to Key dev section

Name: Norway
Overview: In April 2021, the Norges Bank announced that they will begin technical testing for a CBDC. The Governor clarified that Norway is still far from launching a CBDC, but that this announcement marks an advancement in their research.
Key Developments: Norway's central bank, Norges Bank, does not have immediate plans to issue a CBDC, but established an internal working group in 2017 to study digital currencies. In May 2018, the working group released a report identifying key considerations in the decision to develop a CBDC. In June 2019, a second report explored the purposes of a CBDC and assessed potential solutions. In April 2021, the Norges Bank announced they were ready for the next phase in CBDC development: technical testing. This process will take place over the next two year, and involves a more detailed assessment of the proposed solutions, technologies required, and possible implications.

Name: Pakistan
Overview: The State Bank of Pakistan is developing a concept to launch a digital currency by 2025, which coincides with its plan to become fully digital by 2030. However, this concept is still in its infancy and there remain many unknowns on whether the digital currency will be tied to the Pakistani rupee and how it will function.
Key Developments: In April 2019 the State Bank of Pakistan declared it was working on a concept to issue a digital currency by 2025. The stated goals for issuing a digital currency are to promote financial inclusion, and reduce inefficiency and corruption. In addition to issuing a digital currency to promote financial inclusion, the State Bank of Pakistan launched the National Payment Systems Strategy in November of 2019. According to the bank’s governor, Dr. Reza Baqir, “this strategy lays out a road map and action plan for Pakistan to have a modern and robust digital payments network.” While Pakistan’s economy is still cash heavy and digital payments are rare, the State Bank of Pakistan claims that adopting electronic payments will stimulate consumption, which could boost Pakistan’s economy by 7%. In an April 2021 interview, the Dr. Baqir re-emphasized that Pakistan is carefully studying CBDCs and is looking toward countries such as China who have paved the way. Dr. Baqir also teased an announcement in the coming months regarding the state of CBDCs in Pakistan.
Notes: One minor update to key developments section

Name: Palestine
Overview: Both the Palestinian Prime Minister and the Palestine Monetary Authority (PMA) have backed the concept of a CBDC in the country. The PMA announced in 2017 that they planned to launch a digital currency in five years but no further details have since been released.
Key Developments: In May 2017, the head of the PMA Azzam Shawwa announced they were planning to have a digital currency, called the Palestinian pound, within five years. However, there remain significant obstacles for Palestine’s ability to develop a digital currency, as the PMA’s ability to issue currency is limited by the 1994 Paris Protocol agreement. Currently, Palestine does not have its own currency and its money supply consists of the euro, US dollar, Israeli shekel, and Jordanian dinar. In July 2019, the Palestinian Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh backed the PMA’s digital currency efforts, and indicated that the launch of a CBDC would help curb an overreliance reliance on Israeli currency.

Name: Philippines
Overview: The central bank of the Philippines, Bankgo Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), is currently researching a CBDC in accordance with its Digital Payments Transformation Roadmap. There are no intentions to issue a CBDC until at least 2023, but the BSP is closely tracking other countries' progress as well as exploring viability.
Key Developments: In early May 2021, the Bankgo Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) announced that it was looking deeper into the viability of a CBDC. This news follows the October 2020 declaration that a CBDC would not be issued for a while, 2023 at the earliest. During a virtual briefing, BSP Governor Benjamin Diokno stated that the BSP has been closely monitoring the developments of other central bank’s digital currency initiatives, even releasing a report in April. This report contains recommendations for continued research as well as connecting with other central banks working on a CBDC. Importantly, Diokno emphasized that any decisions with a potential CBDC will follow the Digital Payments Transformation Roadmap, released in October 2020. This roadmap has two main objectives, increasing the percentage of retail transactions done digitally to 50% and ensuring that 70% of all adult Filipinos are included in the formal financial system.

Name: Rwanda
Overview: Rwanda is researching a blockchain-based CBDC and they are using the experiences of other central banks' initiatives, including Canada, Singapore, and the Netherlands, to improve their own plans.
Key Developments: The National Bank of Rwanda revealed in 2019 that it is exploring ways to issue a CBDC. Noting outstanding questions around the technology, the National Bank's Financial Stability Director-General Peace Masozera Uwase said, "we will join in once we are ready."

Name: Taiwan
Overview: The Central Bank of Taiwan is exploring the viability of a retail and wholesale CBDC in partnership with private partners and academic institutions, according to a press release from June 2020.
Key Developments: In a press release in June 2020 following the Board of Governors meeting, the Central Bank of Taiwan noted that the focus of bankers exploring CBDCs has shifted from wholesale to retail applications in many countries and that it plans to approach CBDC research in phases: starting with a retail CBDC, and moving on to a wholesale CBDC. The Central Bank of Taiwan has established a working group, in partnership with academic institutions, to explore the technical viability of a DLT-based retail CBDC. It also plans to work with private partners to research a two-tiered wholesale CBDC.
Central Bank Name: Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan)

Name: Tunisia
Overview: Tunisia's blockchain-based e-dinar, issued by the government's post office, has been in circulation since 2015, without central bank involvement. The Central Bank of Tunisia is exploring several digital finance innovations, including a CBDC.
Key Developments: Tunisia's post office partnered with Monetas and DigitUs to offer a blockchain-based digital version of the Tunisian dinar (e-dinar) in 2015. However, the Central Bank of Tunisia was not involved. Online reports surfaced in early November 2019 that Tunisia was starting to develop a CBDC on a blockchain platform in partnership with Russian startup Universa. The Central Bank of Tunisia (Banque Centrale de Tunisie or BCT) denied these reports and clarified that the BCT is researching digital finance innovations, including digital currencies, but it does not have plans to develop a CBDC.

Name: United States of America
Overview: The US Federal Reserve has been actively researching a central bank digital currency (CBDC). At least two prototypes of potential payments systems connected to a digital dollar are near completion. This is being led by officials at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). James Cunha, who leads the project for the Boston Fed, has said that they plan to unveil their research in the Fall of 2021. A research paper from the US Federal Reserve is expected in the summer of 2021.
Key Developments: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell have reaffirmed the US's interest in a digital dollar. At the NYTimes Dealbook Conference, in response to this map, Secretary Yellen said: “I think it [the digital dollar] could result in faster, safer, and cheaper payments, which I think are important goals." During a testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, Powell began by confirming, “We are looking carefully, very carefully at the question of whether we should issue a digital dollar." Individual Federal Reserve Banks are also partnering with various stakeholders on their research. The New York Fed is working with the Bank of International Settlements to identify critical trends and financial technology relevant to central banks. The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston is collaborating with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) to experiment with existing and new technologies that could be used for a digital dollar. In late May 2021, Powell announced that the Federal Reserve will be releasing a research paper later this summer that explores moving forward with the development of a digital dollar. In late September, in anticipation of the report’s release, Powell stated that the Federal Reserve has “made no decision on a CBDC.”

Name: Belarus
Overview: In 2020, Belarus launched a pilot program allowing certain domestic banks to launch tokenized offerings. This program has not yet led to development of CBDC plans.
Central Bank Name: National Bank of the Republic of Belarus

Name: Belize
Overview: The National Bank of Belize (NBB) announced a partnership with financial technology company Bitt in late 2020, aimed at leveraging the company's digital currency management systems to add an eWallet to the bank's mobile payment services.
Key Developments: The NBB eWallet is scheduled to be released to all customers in mid-2021. The wallet uses technology previously employed by Bitt in development of payment services in Barbados and the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank.

Name: Honduras
Overview: On June 11, 2021, the Banco Central de Honduras announced that it would begin research into the possibility of issuing a pilot CBDC.
Key Developments: The Banco Central de Honduras (BCH) announced it has begun an analysis into the conceptual, legal, and technical aspects of a CBDC pilot. Although the BCH acknowledged the global trend toward CBDC adoption, it also added that it is making no guarantee on the future issuance of a digital currency.

Name: New Zealand
Overview: In early July 2021, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand confirmed that it is exploring the potential for a CBDC through a series of public consultations.
Key Developments: Although the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) initially expressed some hesitancy in its approach to CBDC issuance, it announced on July 7, 2021 that it will begin exploring the concept through a series of public consulations. The RBNZ is exploring a CBDC model that will “work alongside cash as government-backed money.” Assistant Governor Christian Hawkesby cited the decline in physical cash use in New Zealand as one of the motivations behind the RBNZ’s interest in a digital currency. Hawkesby stated, “we need to test our assessment of the issues and proposed approach before developing any firm proposals.”

Name: Chile
Overview: Blockchain and CBDC are two of the research topics that the Central Bank of Chile has included in its 2018-2022 Strategic Plan, according to Mario Marcel, Governor of the Central Bank of Chile.
Key Developments: In his remarks at an OECD Forum on Block in September 2019, Mario Marcel, Governor of the Central Bank of Chile, described the two initiatives that the central bank are pursuing to address fintech challenges: the Technological Observatory and the TechLab. The use of blockchain in central banking as well as CBDC are among the topics under these initiatives. However, he noted that "CBDC does not necessarily need blockchain." The central bank is also exploring the feasibility of blockchain-based bonds, with a proof-of-concept ongoing.
